chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: Activiti configuration files should be generated with the setup ant script that can be found in the setup folder. The cfg.create target can be easily configured in the setup/build.properties and the setup/build.${db}.properties. Our QA runs only the configurations that can be generated by the setup script.

section.title: XML configuration file
section.para:
The Activiti process engine is configured through a xml file, by convention in this documentation and in the examples called activiti.cfg.xml. Note that this is only applicable if you're using the ProcessEngineBuilder directly or indirectly through ProcessEngines. This is not applicable if you're using the Spring style of building a process engine. The following snippet shows an example configuration. The following sections will give a detailed overview of each configuration element.
<activiti-cfg process-engine-name="myProcessEngine">
<database type="h2" schema-strategy="true"> <jdbc url="jdbc:h2:mem:activiti;DB_CLOSE_DELAY=1000" driver="org.h2.Driver" username="sa" password="" /> </database>
<job-executor activate="on" />
<history level="audit" />
<mail server="localhost" port="5025" />
</activiti-cfg>

section.title: Configuration root
section.para:
The activiti-cfg element is the root of the Activiti configuration. It supports following attributes:
process-engine-name: The process engine name. Relevant if you're using multiple process engines in one classloading scope.

The activiti-cfg element can be enhanced with an optional namespace declaration (useful for code completion).
<activiti-cfg xmlns="http://activiti.org/cfg" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://activiti.org/cfg http://activiti.org/cfg/activiti-cfg-5.0.xsd" />
See the Eclipse setup section (XML catalog configuration) how to add the configuration schema to the Eclipse XML catalog.

section.title: Database configuration
section.para:
Configures the database that Activiti will use. Currently only supports configuration by passing the jdbc properties (datasource through JNDI will be supported soon). The database allows following attributes:
type: indicates the type of database. This setting will determine which create/drop scripts and queries will be used. See the ''supported databases' section for an overview of which types are supported.
schema-strategy: { false | create-drop } false is the default and it will check if the DB version is the same as the library version when the process engine is created. create-drop is handy for testing. It creates the DB schema when the process engine is created and drops the schema when the engine is closed. Following values are [EXPERIMENTAL]:
create: creates schema when process engine starts.
true: creates schema when process engine starts, when the schema doesn't exist yet. Otherwise doesn't do anything.
drop-create: drops the schema when the process engine starts, and recreates a fresh schema. Useful in testing environments.

The jdbc subelement supports setting the usual jdbc properties as the following attributes (all required):
url: jdbc url of the database.
driver: implementation of the driver for the specific databse type.
username: username to connect to the database.
password: password to connect to the database.

By default, the datasource that is constructed based on the provided jdbc properties will have the default MyBatis connection pool settings. Following attributes can optionally be set to tweak that connection pool (taken from the MyBatis documentation):
max-activie: The number of active connections that the connection pool at maximum at any time can contain. Default is 10.
max-idle: The number of idle connections that the connection pool at maximum at any time can contain.
max-checkout: The amount of time in milliseconds a connection can be 'checked out' from the connection pool before it is forcefully returned. Default is 20000 (20 seconds).
max-wait: This is a low level setting that gives the pool a chance to print a log status and re-attempt the acquisition of a connection in the case that itâ€™s taking unusually long (to avoid failing silently forever if the pool is misconfigured) Default is 20000 (20 seconds).

Example database configuration:
<database type="h2" schema-strategy="true"> <jdbc url="jdbc:h2:mem:activiti;DB_CLOSE_DELAY=1000" driver="org.h2.Driver" username="sa" password="" /> </database>

section.title: Job executor configuration
section.para: Optional element. Only supports one attribute currently: activate, with possible values {on | off}. on is the default which means that the JobExecutor component will start when the process engine is created. In testing, it's best to set this property to off. In that case, the job executor won't be activated and the test can manually search for jobs with ManagementService.createJobQuery and execute them with ManagementService.executeJob.

section.title: Mail server configuration
section.para:
Optional element. Activiti supports sending e-mails in business processes. To actually send an e-mail, a valid SMTP mail server configuration is required. The mail element supports following attributes:
server: Server address of the SMTP mail server.
port: Port of the SMTP mail server. By default port 25.
username: Optional user name for secured SMTP mail servers.
password: Optional password for secured SMTP mail servers.
default-from: Process engine wide setting for the default mail address from which e-mail are sent in business processes. Process definitions can overwrite this process engine wide 'from address' if needed. If this is not the case, the supplied value in default-from will be used. Default value is 'noreply@activiti.org'.
Example mail server configuration: <mail server="localhost" port="5025" default-from="noreply@mycorp.com" />

section.title: History configuration
section.para:
Allows to tweak settings that influence the history capabilities of the engine. Following attributes are supported:
level: possible values are {none | activity | audit | full}, in a ascending order of information that is stored in the history tables.

section.title: Changing the database
section.para:
One of the things you probably want to do fairly soon, is configuring Activiti to use a different database. To generate a configuration file that can be used to configure the engine, following steps need to be done:
Edit setup/build.properties and change the db parameter to your type of database (e.g. mysql).
Edit setup/build.${db}.properties and change the JDBC connection parameters to those of your database installation.
Run 'ant cfg.create' from within the setup folder.
The generate configuration file can now be found in setup/build/activiti-cfg. Also, for convenience, a jar called activiti-cfg.jar containing the configuration file can be found in setup/build

section.title: Using Oracle in the demo setup
section.para:
When you want to run the demo setup using oracle as datasource, an extra step is required BEFORE you call the ant target demo.setup.
Since we cannot redistribute the Oracle JDBC driver due to its licence, you should download it manually: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/enterprise-edition/jdbc-112010-090769.html. Make sure you download ojdbc5.jar, version 11.2.0.1.
Copy the jar to lib/provided/
The only thing left to do is calling the following ant target, in the build-file located in /setup: db.oracle.install.driver The ant-target will actually install the jdbc-driver in the maven repository to be able to use it afterward, using the command:
install:install-file -Dfile=ojdbc5.jar -DgroupId=com.oracle.jdbc -DartifactId=ojdbc5 -Dpackaging=jar -Dversion=11.2.0.1.0 -DcreateChecksum=true -DgeneratePom=true
